rev.diff:
Line 147: Line 147:
The head of the [[Egyptian Shura Council]]'s Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, and also a part of the ruling party, said he does not believe the protests have ended yet.<ref>Breaking News. Al Jazeera English. 29 January, 2011. ~2:00</ref>
The head of the [[Egyptian Shura Council]]'s Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, and also a part of the ruling party, said he does not believe the protests have ended yet.<ref>Breaking News. Al Jazeera English. 29 January, 2011. ~2:00</ref>
â
The Muslim Brotherhood issued a statement following the speech reiterating demands for Mubarak's resignation and saying it was time for the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 | title=Live: Egypt unrest | accessdate=29 January 2011 | date=28 January 2011 | publisher=BBC News Online | archivedate=29 January 2011 | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w5dpTRTE | quote="Mubarak must step down. It is time for the military to intervene and save the country"}}</ref>
+
The Muslim Brotherhood issued a statement following the speech reiterating demands for Mubarak's resignation and saying it was time for the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 | title=Live: Egypt unrest | accessdate=29 January 2011 | date=28 January 2011 | publisher=BBC News Online | archivedate=29 January 2011 | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w5dpTRTE | quote="Mubarak must step down. It is time for the military to intervene and save the country"}}</ref>
  +
==== Media censorship ====
  +
[[File:Unplug-mubarak.gif|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting Hosni Mubarak shutting down Internet, and about to be unplugged (ousted) by the country.]]
  +
Beginning on the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the [[media of Egypt|media outlets inside Egypt]] and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Sarah Kessler|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> which helped protesters spread news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests has been partly attributed to the involvement of tech savvy youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media.
  +
On 27 January, it was reported on Twitter by many Egyptian and foreign reporters on the ground that the government had blocked text messaging and [[BlackBerry]] messaging services.<ref name="BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt">{{cite web|author=Leena Rao|url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/01/27/blackberry-internet-service-reportedly-blocked-in-egypt|title=BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt|publisher=[[Techcrunch]]|date=2011-01-27|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> [[censorship of Twitter|Twitter]] was sporadically blocked,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/4773.aspx |title=Live updates: Opposition groups protest on Police Day - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=John Ribeiro |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9206459/Twitter_blocked_in_Egypt_after_political_unrest |title=Twitter blocked in Egypt after political unrest |publisher=Computerworld |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=January 25, 2011 by Sarah Kessler View Comments |url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/25/twitter-blocked-in-egypt/ |title=Twitter Blocked in Egypt As Protests Turn Violent |publisher=Mashable.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> then [[censorship of Facebook|Facebook]].<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt_n_814586.html Facebook blocked in Egypt] [[Huffington Post]] 2011/01/26</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Tarek Amr, Egypt |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/28/egypt-an-internet-blackhole/ |title=Egypt: An Internet Black Hole Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> Al Jazeera said its television transmission had to be switched to another frequency as its signal on Nilesat was jammed.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-withdraws-from-web-blocks-phones-after-protesters-take-to-streets.html Egypt Withdraws From Web, Blocks Phones After Protesters Take to Streets]</ref>
  +   +
==== Total Internet blackout ====
  +
Starting just after midnight local time on 28 January<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> the Egyptian government almost entirely cut off Egypt from the rest of the Internet<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock">{{cite web| last =Cowie| first =James| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Egypt Leaves the Internet| work =| publisher =[[Renesys]]| date =| url =http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml | doi =| accessdate =2011-01-28 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w51j0pga |archivedate=2011-01-28 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock">{{cite news | first=Jeremy | last=Kirk | pages= | language =| title=With Wired Internet Locked, Egypt Looks to the Sky | date=2011-01-28 | publisher=[[IDG News]]/[[PC World]] | url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/218064/with_wired_internet_locked_egypt_looks_to_the_sky.html |accessdate=2011-01-28 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w518Yu9B |archivedate=2011-01-28 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pomed.org/blog/2011/01/egypt-ap-confirms-government-has-disrupted-internet-service.html/ |title=Egypt: AP Confirms Government has Disrupted Internet Service |publisher=pomed.org |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> in an act of unprecedented<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock" /> [[Internet censorship]]. About 3,500 [[Border Gateway Protocol]] (BGP) routes to Egyptian networks were shut down from about 12:10am to 12:35am 27 January.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> The shutdown happened within the space of a few tens of minutes, not instantaneously. According to Renesys, [[Telecom Egypt]] started shutting down at 12:12am, [[Vodaphone|Raya/Vodaphone]] at 12:13am, [[Link Egypt]] at 12:17am, [[Etisalat Misr]] at 12:19am, and [[Internet Egypt]] at 12:25am.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Renesys interpreted the shutdown as people getting phone calls one at a time, telling them to take themselves off the air, rather than an automated system taking all providers down at once.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Facebook confirmed a decrease in traffic from Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-54463420110127|title=Facebook says has seen drop in traffic from Egypt|publisher=Reuters|author=Alexei Oreskovic/Doina Chiacu|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> A [[Border Gateway Protocol]] monitoring site in [[Vancouver, Canada]], reported most of the primary AS (ISPs) dropping a large percentage if not all of route advertisements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bgpmon.net/blog/?p=450|title=BGPMon.net|publisher=bgpmon.net|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> Virtually all of Egypt's Internet addresses were unreachable, worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/27/egypt-internet-goes-down-_n_815156.html |title=Egypt's Internet Shut Down, According To Reports |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
  +   +
In response, the U.S. State Department spokesman Philip Crowley said that open communications must be allowed.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-withdraws-from-web-blocks-phones-after-protesters-take-to-streets.html Egypt Withdraws From Web, Blocks Phones After Protesters Take to Streets]</ref> About 24 hours after the blackout began, cellphone and smartphone e-mail access were restored, including Vodaphone and Mobinil, though internet access was reportedly still down.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-general/20110128/ML.Egypt.Protest/|title= Protesters return to Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=AP/Comcast|date=2011-01-29|accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
==== Mubarak dismisses the government ====
==== Mubarak dismisses the government ====
Line 179: Line 188:
On Wednesday 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html|title=Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2011-01-16|author=Ahmed A Namatalla}}</ref> The EGX30 has dropped almost 1000 points since 13 January 2011. EGX dropped 6.1% on 26 January, and then another 6.2% on 27 January, before the chief of the stock market temporarily suspended trading<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE70Q0PT20110127 |title=Egypt Bourse suspends trade after index slides |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> due to marked losing of points in the first minutes of the opening session. The stock index closed the day down by 10.5%.<ref>http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-economy/2011/01/riots_in_egypt_weigh_heavily_o.html</ref>
On Wednesday 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html|title=Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2011-01-16|author=Ahmed A Namatalla}}</ref> The EGX30 has dropped almost 1000 points since 13 January 2011. EGX dropped 6.1% on 26 January, and then another 6.2% on 27 January, before the chief of the stock market temporarily suspended trading<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE70Q0PT20110127 |title=Egypt Bourse suspends trade after index slides |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> due to marked losing of points in the first minutes of the opening session. The stock index closed the day down by 10.5%.<ref>http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-economy/2011/01/riots_in_egypt_weigh_heavily_o.html</ref>
â
On 28 January, [[Fitch Ratings]] changed Egypt's rating outlook to negative from stable, saying the upsurge in protests adds uncertainty to the political and economic outlook.<ref name="Bloomberg-Muslim-Brotherhood">{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-s-muslim-botherhood-says-police-detain-senior-leaders-after-protests.html|title=Mubarak Faces His Biggest Challenge Amid Nationwide Protests|date=2011-01-28|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Vivian Salama, Ola Galal and Caroline Alexander}}</ref> Egyptian dollar-denominated bond yields also rose to a record high as oil prices rose and global stock market indices sank.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/asian-stocks-fall-for-first-time-in-five-days-on-japan-outlook-oil-slides.html|title=Oil Jumps, Stocks Retreat Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Stephen Kirkland|date=2011-01-28}}</ref> International [[gold]] prices jumped the most in 12 weeks by over US$20 to US$1341.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/gold-rises-from-lowest-since-october-on-outlook-for-u-s-interest-rates.html</ref> The international price of oil rose US$3.70 (4.3%) to US$89.34 on concern the instability would spread, the highest price since September 2009.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html</ref>
+
On 28 January, [[Fitch Ratings]] changed Egypt's rating outlook to negative from stable, saying the upsurge in protests adds uncertainty to the political and economic outlook.<ref name="Bloomberg-Muslim-Brotherhood">{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-s-muslim-botherhood-says-police-detain-senior-leaders-after-protests.html|title=Mubarak Faces His Biggest Challenge Amid Nationwide Protests|date=2011-01-28|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Vivian Salama, Ola Galal and Caroline Alexander}}</ref> Egyptian dollar-denominated bond yields also rose to a record high as oil prices rose and global stock market indices sank.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/asian-stocks-fall-for-first-time-in-five-days-on-japan-outlook-oil-slides.html|title=Oil Jumps, Stocks Retreat Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Stephen Kirkland|date=2011-01-28}}</ref> International [[gold]] prices jumped the most in 12 weeks by over US$20 to US$1341.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/gold-rises-from-lowest-since-october-on-outlook-for-u-s-interest-rates.html</ref> The international price of oil rose US$3.70 (4.3%) to US$89.34 on concern the instability would spread, the highest price since September 2009.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html</ref>
â   â
==== Media censorship ====
  â
[[File:Unplug-mubarak.gif|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting Hosni Mubarak shutting down Internet, and about to be unplugged (ousted) by the country.]]
  â
Beginning on the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the [[media of Egypt|media outlets inside Egypt]] and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Sarah Kessler|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> which helped protesters spread news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests has been partly attributed to the involvement of tech savvy youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media.
  â   â
On 27 January, it was reported on Twitter by many Egyptian and foreign reporters on the ground that the government had blocked text messaging and [[BlackBerry]] messaging services.<ref name="BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt">{{cite web|author=Leena Rao|url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/01/27/blackberry-internet-service-reportedly-blocked-in-egypt|title=BlackBerry Internet Service Reportedly Blocked In Egypt|publisher=[[Techcrunch]]|date=2011-01-27|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> [[censorship of Twitter|Twitter]] was sporadically blocked,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/4773.aspx |title=Live updates: Opposition groups protest on Police Day - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=John Ribeiro |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9206459/Twitter_blocked_in_Egypt_after_political_unrest |title=Twitter blocked in Egypt after political unrest |publisher=Computerworld |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=January 25, 2011 by Sarah Kessler View Comments |url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/25/twitter-blocked-in-egypt/ |title=Twitter Blocked in Egypt As Protests Turn Violent |publisher=Mashable.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> then [[censorship of Facebook|Facebook]].<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt_n_814586.html Facebook blocked in Egypt] [[Huffington Post]] 2011/01/26</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Tarek Amr, Egypt |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/28/egypt-an-internet-blackhole/ |title=Egypt: An Internet Black Hole Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> Al Jazeera said its television transmission had to be switched to another frequency as its signal on Nilesat was jammed.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-withdraws-from-web-blocks-phones-after-protesters-take-to-streets.html Egypt Withdraws From Web, Blocks Phones After Protesters Take to Streets]</ref>
  â   â
====Total Internet blackout====
  â
Starting just after midnight local time on 28 January<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> the Egyptian government almost entirely cut off Egypt from the rest of the Internet<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock">{{cite web| last =Cowie| first =James| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Egypt Leaves the Internet| work =| publisher =[[Renesys]]| date =| url =http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml | doi =| accessdate =2011-01-28 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w51j0pga |archivedate=2011-01-28 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock">{{cite news | first=Jeremy | last=Kirk | pages= | language =| title=With Wired Internet Locked, Egypt Looks to the Sky | date=2011-01-28 | publisher=[[IDG News]]/[[PC World]] | url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/218064/with_wired_internet_locked_egypt_looks_to_the_sky.html |accessdate=2011-01-28 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w518Yu9B |archivedate=2011-01-28 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pomed.org/blog/2011/01/egypt-ap-confirms-government-has-disrupted-internet-service.html/ |title=Egypt: AP Confirms Government has Disrupted Internet Service |publisher=pomed.org |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> in an act of unprecedented<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /><ref name="IDGnews_Egyptfullblock" /> [[Internet censorship]]. About 3,500 [[Border Gateway Protocol]] (BGP) routes to Egyptian networks were shut down from about 12:10am to 12:35am 27 January.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> The shutdown happened within the space of a few tens of minutes, not instantaneously. According to Renesys, [[Telecom Egypt]] started shutting down at 12:12am, [[Vodaphone|Raya/Vodaphone]] at 12:13am, [[Link Egypt]] at 12:17am, [[Etisalat Misr]] at 12:19am, and [[Internet Egypt]] at 12:25am.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Renesys interpreted the shutdown as people getting phone calls one at a time, telling them to take themselves off the air, rather than an automated system taking all providers down at once.<ref name="jamescowie_techdetails_Egyptfullblock" /> Facebook confirmed a decrease in traffic from Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-54463420110127|title=Facebook says has seen drop in traffic from Egypt|publisher=Reuters|author=Alexei Oreskovic/Doina Chiacu|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> A [[Border Gateway Protocol]] monitoring site in [[Vancouver, Canada]], reported most of the primary AS (ISPs) dropping a large percentage if not all of route advertisements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bgpmon.net/blog/?p=450|title=BGPMon.net|publisher=bgpmon.net|date=2011-01-28|accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> Virtually all of Egypt's Internet addresses were unreachable, worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/27/egypt-internet-goes-down-_n_815156.html |title=Egypt's Internet Shut Down, According To Reports |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
  â   â
In response, the U.S. State Department spokesman Philip Crowley said that open communications must be allowed.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-withdraws-from-web-blocks-phones-after-protesters-take-to-streets.html Egypt Withdraws From Web, Blocks Phones After Protesters Take to Streets]</ref> About 24 hours after the blackout began, cellphone and smartphone e-mail access were restored, including Vodaphone and Mobinil, though internet access was reportedly still down.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-general/20110128/ML.Egypt.Protest/|title= Protesters return to Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=AP/Comcast|date=2011-01-29|accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
